data.title: Screen "add" function is not recalled when a variable is updated
data.body:
It is easy to reproduce with the script publicated here: 
http://www.renpy.org/wiki/renpy/doc/cookbook/Adding_a_simple_Analog_Clock

The code works fine in old renpy (for example 6.13), but doesnt work in the last builds (the clockhands don't rotate when 'minutes' changed).

data.title: $ renpy.pause() is not working in auto-play mode
data.body:
In **6.99.7.858**,
**$ renpy.pause()** is not working in my replay labels.

data.title: There is no "Call" action usable as a button action
data.body:
Hi, I started a thread in this forum and pointed a lack of "Call" action usable in button's action.
Here is a complete explanation of the problem: http://lemmasoft.renai.us/forums/viewtopic.php?p=393761#p393761

Basically:

```
screen special_actions_screen():
    window id "special_actions_window":
        # place the window on the right of the screen
        vbox:
            # ...
            button:
                text "Punch In The Face"
                action Jump("on_punch_1") # OK, but never return!
            button:
                text "Smile/Grin"
                action Call("on_smile_1") # ERROR: Call is not defined
```

I need a Call action to be able to return from a label (see the thread for a full example of my use case) exactly like when you use the "call" statement.

My current "hack" (which seems to work is):

```
                action Function(Renpy.call, "on_smile_1") # Equivalent to "call on_smile_1"
```

However I suspect that this is not the intended way to use button's action property. Jump action don't allow me to return from a label as it is equivalent to a "jump" statement.

Therefore I think that a Call action is missing (in the documentation too).

I could provide a patch but I see several ways of doing this and I'm not familiar with this codebase so I might need guidance if there are hidden difficulties with this.

Also, I don't understand why this is not already available. Is there some complexities with this feature that I am not perceiving? Or maybe it have just been forgotten? I suspect that a lot of people would have needed to do this so I'm a bit lost as to why it's not already available.

data.title: Newer versions of cython can generate Python longs.
data.body:
I get the following error when trying to run 32bit renpy >= 6.99.6 within chroot under amd64 on FreeBSD 11. Bisecting leads to 22a1bc6.

``` shell
$ pkg info -x cython sdl
cython-0.23.4
py27-game_sdl2-6.99.7
sdl2-2.0.3_6
sdl2_image-2.0.0_7
sdl2_mixer-2.0.0_9
sdl2_ttf-2.0.12_5
```

data.title: Hyperlink highlight problem.
data.body: http://lemmasoft.renai.us/forums/viewtopic.php?p=392217#p392217

data.title: No longer try to reuse existing windows when switching video modes.
data.body:
This fixes a bug where, if you're using the software renderer on Xorg on Debian Jessie,
switching into fullscreen produces an unusable screen (usually, a fullscreen window with
the current screen contents stuck on it; sometimes the game window scaled to full screen
but refusing to accept graphic updates (though clicks ARE passed through to the underlying
game), sometimes the game window drawn actual size in the upper left corner of the screen
with the rest of the screen occupied by the previous screen contents).  This bug was
seen on two different Jessie machines.

The fix doesn't appear to cause problems on my Win8 test machine; I haven't tested it on anything else.  There doesn't seem to be any real performance benefit from the window reuse on Jessie or Win8.

data.title: Lint false positive on image lookup for "scene" statement
data.body:
The `lint.image_exists` function has a `precise` argument, which has value `True` when called to check image existence for a `scene` statement. However, the lookup performed under the "Look for the precise name." comment requires the image attributes to be in a certain order, while during execution the order of attributes (beyond the tag) does not matter.

The following example makes lint complain "The image named 'bg attrib_1 attrib_0' was not declared.", but it executes without errors and shows the yellow background:

```
image bg attrib_0 attrib_1 = Solid('#ffff00')
label start:
    scene bg attrib_1 attrib_0
```

data.title: update
data.body: update

data.title: Added deprecation warnings on UI Functions
SW rendering bugfix and minor changes
data.body:
This fixes a bug where exposure events didn't properly redraw the window on X if a player's using software rendering.  (Observed on two separate Debian machines, one with a Radeon and an OLPC with a Geode; neither have proprietary drivers installed.)

To reproduce the bug:
RENPY_RENDER=sw ./renpy.sh
Move another window partially over the launcher
move the window back off

The contents of the other window will be stuck atop the Ren'Py window until Ren'Py actually redraws that section of the screen.

This pull req also adds support for home and end in text input fields, and widens the cursor to two pixels to work around a bug where one-pixel-wide input field cursors don't show up on software rendering.  (This was observed on both Debian and El Capitan)

```

Windows-8-6.2.9200
Ren'Py 6.99.6.739
TheWedding 0.0.1
```

data.title: Movie loop's lag
data.body:
**tl;dr** Cache/buffer videos pls?

That problem was skimmed on the forum a few years ago, I think. Video playback performance is poor when it comes to loops. What it does is basically skips a few frames of video hence breaking seamless transition.
As far as I can tell this problem is OS agnostic and has been around for a while. Can't RenPy buffer a video file? The code explicitly states that apart from audio files buffering of video is prohibited which seems to be the shatter point.

I understand this may seem like insignificant feature for a visual novel engine, but it's 2015. We have rich multimedia support on so many devices. Plus looping of video files is already baked in the engine but the described flaw kind of cancels it. We have ATL for simple stuff but no gif, apng (you name it) support for rich animation so the video is the only solution. 

The most basic use case of it is looping video background in the main menu — a question that pops up on the forum every now and then.

data.title: Dialogue window background not predicted
data.body:
If different characters have different background images for the dialogue window, prediction only works for the first window. I traced it to `renpy.display.predict.prediction_coroutine`, where the loop at the end refuses to call `renpy.display.screen.predict_screen` for the second dialogue window and beyond, since `predicted_screens` already contains `"say"`.

Maybe this is caused by the changes made to solve #747?

data.title: Add "arrowkeys" child to Viewport
data.body:
I figure if "mousewheel" is a child, it might be nice to be able to have "arrowkeys" as a child... but I'm not entirely certain as to the correctness of the script changes.

It works on my end, but it may not be stylistically correct.

data.title: Custom text replacement hook
data.body: This allows a custom function to for example replace '--' with em-dash and '...' with an actual ellipsis character. While it is possible to instead put those Unicode characters directly in the .rpy file, it is easier to type them as ASCII sequences.

data.title: Initial implementation of Displayable Inspector showing absolute x,y
data.body:
Sample code I was using: https://gist.github.com/Rikxz/19951178f445692ffa7e

I figured it was easier to bring it up here instead of in IRC, to show what exactly I was trying.  I'm mostly trying to figure out... why in the world it's _not_ working.  What am I missing?

Also is it just completely a bad idea for Renpy as implemented?  When doing some UI stuff I was wanting this sort of information very badly.
